{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:13.199

    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:26.960
    | text      = In short, to change how people think by stimulating the brain.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:29.760
    | text      = Boston University researcher Robert Reinhardt used a new form of brain stimulation called
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:33.960
    | text      = high definition transcranial alternating current stimulation, also known as HD tax, to turbo
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:40.219
    | text      = charge two brain regions that influence how we learn.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:43.360
    | text      = If you make an error, this brain area fires.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:46.280

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:49.159
    | text      = If something surprises you, it fires, Reinhardt said in a BU research press release, referring
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:54.320
    | text      = to the medial frontal cortex, which he calls the quote alarm bell of the brain.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:59.880
    | text      = Reinhardt and his colleagues found that stimulating this region as well as the lateral prefrontal
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:03.760

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = self control.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:12.199
    | text      = So they published a study about this and here's what they did.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:15.400
    | text      = Reinhardt's team tested 30 healthy people, each wearing a soft cap with electrodes that
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:19.260
    | text      = conveyed the stimulation.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:20.900
    | text      = The test was simple.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:22.119
    | text      = Each subject had to press a button every 1.7 seconds.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:25.480
    | text      = In the first three rounds of tests, the researchers either cranked up the synchronicity between
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:29.480
    | text      = the two lobes, disrupted it, or did nothing.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:32.619
    | text      = The participants brain activity monitored by an electroencephalogram, or an EEG, showed
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:37.880
    | text      = statistically significant results.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:40.280
    | text      = When the brain waves were upped, the subjects learned faster and made fewer mistakes, which
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = they correct, when they made the mistakes, they corrected them abruptly.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:48.440
    | text      = When the brain wave was disrupted, they made more errors and learned more slowly.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
